turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about European migrant crisis.
turn.1: What country is responsible for the distribution of migrants?
turn.2: By default (when no family reasons or humanitarian grounds are present), the first member state that an asylum seeker entered and in which they have been fingerprinted is responsible.
turn.3: can they be returned to their country of origin?
turn.4: If the asylum seeker then moves to another member state, they can be transferred back to the member state they first entered.
turn.5: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.6: This has led many to criticise the Dublin rules for placing too much responsibility for asylum seekers on member states on the EU's external borders (like Italy, Greece and Hungary), instead of devising a burden-sharing system among EU states.
turn.8: In June 2016, the Commission to the European Parliament and Council addressed "inherent weaknesses" in the Common European Asylum System and proposed reforms for the Dublin Regulation.
turn.10: Under the initial Dublin Regulation, responsibility was concentrated on border states that received a large influx of asylum seekers.
turn.12: A briefing by the European Parliament explained that the Dublin Agreement was only designed to assign responsibility, not effectively share responsibility.
